R: 1, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), 40,  The combination of joint pain, fever, cardiac disease, and renal disease are common manifestations of SLE, an autoimmune disorder that can affect multiple organ systems.
R: 2, Scleroderma, 30,  The tight skin, Raynaud's phenomenon (finger turning blue), and trouble swallowing are characteristic of scleroderma, a connective tissue disorder that causes hardening and tightening of the skin and organs.
R: 3, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), 15,  The joint pain, fever, and splenomegaly can be seen in JIA, an autoimmune disorder that causes joint inflammation and can affect other organs.
R: 4, Vasculitis, 10,  The finger turning blue, renal disease, and cardiac disease can be manifestations of vasculitis, an inflammation of blood vessels that can affect various organs.
R: 5, Juvenile Dermatomyositis, 5,  The joint pain, tight skin, and trouble swallowing can be seen in juvenile dermatomyositis, an autoimmune disorder that causes muscle weakness and skin rashes.

R: 1, Juvenile Dermatomyositis, 40,  Joint tenderness, muscular weakness, and lung involvement (restrictive lung disease and abnormal diffusion) are common manifestations of this autoimmune condition affecting muscles and skin.
R: 2, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), 25,  This autoimmune disorder can also present with joint pain, muscle weakness, and lung involvement, particularly in children and adolescents.
R: 3, Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), 15,  MCTD is an overlap syndrome that can exhibit features of various autoimmune diseases, including joint pain, muscle weakness, and lung manifestations.
R: 4, Scleroderma, 10,  While more common in adults, scleroderma can occur in children and may involve joint pain, muscle weakness, and lung fibrosis leading to restrictive lung disease.
R: 5, Rheumatoid Arthritis, 10,  Although less common in children, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis can cause joint tenderness, muscle weakness, and, in some cases, lung involvement.

R: 2, Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), 20,  The combination of Raynaud's phenomenon, joint stiffness, muscle weakness, and hypertension can be seen in MCTD, which is an overlap syndrome with features of systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis.
R: 3, Juvenile Dermatomyositis, 10,  The rash on the cheeks and hands, along with muscle weakness, can be indicative of juvenile dermatomyositis, an inflammatory myopathy affecting children.
R: 4, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis, 5,  Joint stiffness and rash can be seen in some forms of juvenile idiopathic arthritis, although the other symptoms are less typical.
R: 5, Eosinophilic Esophagitis, 5,  Trouble swallowing solids can be a symptom of eosinophilic esophagitis, an allergic inflammatory condition of the esophagus, although the other symptoms are not commonly associated with this condition.

S:Hepatomegaly
R: 1, Glycogen Storage Disease, 40,  Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) is a common symptom of glycogen storage diseases, which are inherited disorders that affect the body's ability to break down or store glycogen, a form of stored carbohydrate. Sore muscles and cold hands can also be associated with these conditions.
R: 2, Hypothyroidism, 30,  Hypothyroidism, or an underactive thyroid, can cause symptoms such as cold intolerance (including cold hands), muscle weakness or pain, and in some cases, hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of glycogen in the liver.
R: 3, Muscular Dystrophy, 15,  Certain types of muscular dystrophy, such as Duchenne muscular dystrophy, can cause muscle weakness or pain, and in some cases, hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of fat or glycogen in the liver. Cold hands may also occur due to poor circulation.
R: 4, Metabolic Disorder, 10,  Various metabolic disorders, such as fatty acid oxidation disorders or organic acidemias, can cause symptoms like muscle pain, hepatomegaly, and cold extremities due to the buildup of toxic metabolites or energy deficiency.
R: 5, Infectious Disease, 5,  While less likely, certain infectious diseases, such as viral hepatitis or mononucleosis, can cause hepatomegaly, muscle pain, and potentially cold extremities due to the body's immune response or associated complications.

R: 4, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis, 5,  Joint stiffness, fever, and rash can be seen in certain types of juvenile idiopathic arthritis, although the other symptoms are less typical.
R: 5, Vasculitis, 5,  Vasculitis can affect multiple organ systems, including the skin (rash), joints (stiffness), lungs, and gastrointestinal tract, and may explain some of the symptoms.

R: 3, Juvenile Dermatomyositis, 20,  Muscular weakness, skin changes (shiny skin), and lung involvement (abnormal diffusion) are seen in juvenile dermatomyositis, an inflammatory myopathy.
R: 4, Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), 15,  MCTD can present with features of SLE, scleroderma, and myositis, including joint tenderness, Raynaud's phenomenon, and muscular weakness.
R: 5, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), 10,  Joint tenderness and effusion can be seen in JIA, an autoimmune arthritis that affects children.

R: 3, Dermatomyositis, 20,  Shiny skin, muscular weakness, and joint tenderness are characteristic symptoms of dermatomyositis, which is an inflammatory muscle disease that can also affect the skin.

R: 2, Scleroderma, 25,  Raynaud's phenomenon (finger turning blue) and shiny skin (due to skin tightening) are characteristic features of scleroderma, while joint pain and hepatomegaly can also occur in some cases.
R: 3, Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), 15,  MCTD can present with a combination of symptoms seen in lupus, scleroderma, and other connective tissue disorders, including joint pain, Raynaud's phenomenon, and hepatomegaly.
R: 4, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA), 10,  Joint pain is a prominent feature of JIA, and some subtypes of JIA can also involve skin manifestations and hepatomegaly.
R: 5, Polyarteritis Nodosa, 10,  This vasculitis can cause joint pain, Raynaud's phenomenon, skin changes, and hepatomegaly due to liver involvement.

R: 2, Raynaud's Phenomenon, 25,  Finger turning blue could be a sign of Raynaud's, a condition that causes poor blood circulation in the extremities.
R: 3, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), 15,  Tight skin, joint pain, fever, and muscular weakness can be manifestations of SLE, an autoimmune disorder affecting multiple organs.
R: 4, Dermatomyositis, 10,  Tight skin, muscular weakness, and fever are characteristic of dermatomyositis, an inflammatory condition affecting the skin and muscles.
R: 5, Scleroderma, 10,  Tight skin and Raynaud's phenomenon are common in scleroderma, an autoimmune disorder causing hardening and tightening of the skin.
